title-group.article-title: Microsimulation Modeling of Student Success in Community Colleges Using MicroCC

bio.title: Bios
bio.p: Martin Spielauer (martin@spielauer.ca) is a microsimulation consultant in Ottawa, Canada. Dr. Spielauer is a demographer with a background in economics, statistics, and computer science. He has been working on microsimulations for over a decade.

Ronald E. Anderson (rea@umn.edu) is the professor emeritus at the University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN. He is also coeditor of the Social Science Computer Review. His previous simulation work was on prison sentencing and inmate careers.

author-notes.corresp: Ronald E. Anderson, University of Minnesota, 663 Bushaway Rd, Wayzata, MN 55391, USA Email: rea@umn.edu

abstract.p: While microsimulation modeling has not been utilized extensively in either social science or educational research, it offers to greatly improve understanding, especially of careers and institutional changes over time. The MicroCC microsimulation model was developed and tested on over 250,000 community college students who enrolled in Connecticut and Rhode Island. MicroCC simulated term-by-term progress and completion of new students for 4.5 years. Using data-based effect coefficients, the model simulated decisions for four process factors: re-enrollment, full-time attendance, the number of courses taken, and course completions. The model allowed decomposition of racial, gender, and other differences in success rates by process factors. The findings have major relevance for improving student success rates, especially by suggesting ways to make student advising more effective. Besides serving as an analytical tool, MicroCC allows projection of completion rates under “what-if” scenarios. Illustrative input data for MicroCC and a user and access guide are given in appendices.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Microsimulation as an analytical tool for policy analysis has grown in sophistication and popularity across many fields in the past decade (Anderson & Hicks, 2011). While education attainment is an important variable in virtually all large dynamic microsimulation models, no microsimulation models until now were designed to investigate college student completion trajectories based on detailed longitudinal enrollment databases. Education is generally embedded in models of labor markets, family, tax, pension, and welfare systems (Spielauer, 2004). For example, the LifePaths model in Canada (Statistics Canada, 2001) and SESIM (SESIM, 1999) in Sweden are large multipurpose life-course models allowing exploration of the effects of educational policies. Boothby and Rowe (2002) also used LifePaths to study individual-level rates of return to education.

Education has been identified as the single most important, observable source of population heterogeneity after age and sex (Lutz, Goujon, & Doblhammer-Reiter, 1999). Education thus constitutes a key variable in demographic projections. Differences in educational attainment by ethnocultural group were explicitly modeled in Statistic Canada's Demosim microsimulation (Spielauer, 2011). However, none of these microsimulations actually modeled enrollment and completion behaviors of students across multiple terms.

In the past 5 years, poor college completion rates in the United States, especially among 2-year colleges (called community colleges in the United Statesd), have become a matter of great concern. Typically, only 40% of community college students complete a degree, a certificate, or transfer into a 4-year program within 5 years of first enrollment. Many national and regional initiatives have been launched to improve completion success rates of students attending community colleges. These projects emphasize data-driven approaches but have generally used trend data rather than longitudinal records such as used in this project.

In this report, we describe the MicroCC microsimulation model which was developed to respond to the demands for analytic research tools for an enhanced understanding of student pathways to success. As part of this project, with the help of the New England Board on Higher Education (NEBHE), the Connecticut Community College System, and the Rhode Island Community College we produced two customized student enrollment databases. This report mainly focuses on the decomposition of student’s success across different ethnic groups, gender, and programs.

sec.title: Data and Statistical Models
sec.p: Our analysis is based on three groups of individual student enrollees, each with their own histories of enrollment and success. One group consisted of all the Rhode Island Community College students who enrolled for the first time in the fall of 2005. The other two groups were from the Connecticut (CT) system, one group was limited to only those students who majored in an advanced technology program (ATP) and the other group was all of the remaining students in the seven cohorts starting in the fall terms of 1999 through 2005. All students were followed over 4.5 years (9 terms), not including the summer terms. The Rhode Island cohort had only 2,502 students, but the CT technology group included 7,310 students and the CT nontechnology student group consisted of 121,833 students. We excluded from the CT sample those students who started after 2005, so that all student trajectories were based upon 9 terms of data.
The databases contained the following characteristics:

list-item.p: Background factors of gender, race, age at first enrollment, and whether the first term enrollment was full time (vs. part time);

The term-by-term intermediate student decisions and behaviors: (1) the decision to re-enroll (or not) for each term; (2) the choice to enroll full time or part time each term; (3) the decision, based upon that choice, of how many courses to take during that term; (4) and the behavior of actually passing rather than failing each course attempted.

sec.p: The background factors are time invariant and define the universe of characteristics in the starting population which is created from a frequency table of the students’ characteristics observed in the three databases (see Figure 3 and Appendix A). Thus, for each initial enrollment cohort, the distributions are parameterized by sex, initial full-time/part-time enrollment, four racial groups (White, Black, Asian, and other) and two age groups (below or equal/above 22). The size of the simulated population can be set by the user. We iterated the process enough times to produce the equivalent of a population size of 5 million students, which is large enough to virtually eliminate Monte Carlo variability.

The term-to-term decision data correspond with the main behavioral modules of MicroCC. At the beginning of each term, it is first decided whether a student enrolls/re-enrolls, if he or she studies full or part time and how many courses are taken. At the end of each term, the study success of each of the courses taken is determined on a pass/fail basis. For the MicroCC model, nearly 42 separate logistic regression models were estimated to generate the effects of background factors on intermediate student choice and behaviors (see Appendix A). Our analyses reveal significant differences in all four behaviors by ethnic group, gender, and study program. How each of these differences ultimately translates into differences in success rates is illustrated in the next section.

While many alternative success criteria were explored, the success criterion used in for the CT data was completion of 12 credit-based courses within 9 terms. This simple criterion made it possible to study students’ success without distinguishing the alternative successful outcomes, namely completion of a 2-year program or transfer to a 4-year program, which were not available from our CT data source. The Rhode Island success criteria included one of the following: a degree, certificate, transfer to a 4-year institution, or completion of 12 credit-based courses within 9 terms.

sec.title: The MicroCC Model Implementation
sec.p: The MicroCC model is implemented in Modgen, a generic microsimulation programming language developed and maintained at Statistics Canada and widely used in social science microsimulation. Like all Modgen applications, MicroCC has an attractive user interface (see Figure 3) and can be published on the web. Users thus can study the model, model scenarios, and model results of public runs over the Internet; logged in users can also create and run their own scenarios. The current version is a standard Windows version. More information on Modgen, including download information for Modgen and MicroCC, is provided in Appendix B.

sec.title: Explaining the Hispanic-White Success Difference in Rhode Island
sec.p: Once the validity of the baseline simulation was confirmed by performing retrospective projections, the MicroCC model was used as a scenario tool to ask “what-if questions.” For example, we obtained answers to the scenario question, what if the male–female gap in “average number of courses taken” was closed, how would this affect the gender gap in success rates over time. More often, we asked, what if the gap in all four student decisions and intermediate behaviors were closed for any two background categories, how would this affect the overall success rates? If one of our four background factors had been participation in an intervention program, then we could have answered the question, “Suppose all of the students experienced the intervention program, how would that change the overall success rate of the students over time?”

In order to understand the factors that explain a success rate gap based upon background variables such as race, it is necessary to run a “what if” scenario. In Figure 1, the scenario estimated by the microsimulation was “what if the Hispanic Student success rate was forced to be equal to that of the White students.” The data for this simulation consisted of the 2,502 students in Rhode Island, where the White student success rate was 17% higher than the Hispanic rate.

caption.p: Microsimulation results showing role of student decisions in closing the 17% gap between white and Hispanic students in success rates for Rhode Island Community College 2,502 student cohort in 2005.

sec.p: The histogram shown in Figure 1 depicts the role of each of the four student decisions in accounting for the gap between Whites and Hispanics with blocks to the right of the main bar. The area above these blocks marked with a 2-directional arrow is the portion of the gap that remains unexplained by the student decisions, but resulting from external factors such as socioeconomic status and parent’s education. The sizes of the blocks show that the race gap here was due mostly to the effect of re-enrollments, enrolling full time versus part time, and the effect of the number of courses attempted. The fourth factor, effect of differential course success, had a negative effect on the gap and its block is depicted below the 0.0 line. Apparently, Hispanics had a higher probability of passing courses than Whites, but they were less likely to re-enroll, enroll full time, and take a large number of courses. The largest block representing the largest effect size is the decision to enroll full time versus part time.

We found that around half of the ethnic differences in study success can be attributed to the different initial full-time enrollment rates, while the contributions of other factors like differences in dropout rates, course repetition, and the number of courses taken are highly specific to ethnic groups.

sec.title: Overall Trends in CT Success Rates
sec.p: Besides its use for decomposition analysis demonstrated above, MicroCC is a projection tool that can account for the changing composition of the student population over time. CT student history data indicate increasing success rates for both the advanced technology and nontechnology cohorts for 2000–2004. Comparing these observed rates with MicroCC predictions (Figure 2) reveals that this increase can entirely be attributed to the changing composition of students by sex, race, age, and initial full-time/part-time status, because the behavioral models—which do not include any time trends in behaviors—almost perfectly reproduce the observed rates. In the absence of behavioral changes, the changing composition of students reflected in the enrollment data of entry cohorts after 2004 will lead to a continued upward trend in success rates. More in-depth analysis has shown that the increase in success rates can mainly be attributed to the increasing initial full-time rates in the older age group of (especially White) students. In Figure 2, the jagged trend lines result from the fact that those who start as new students in the spring term have a radically different composition and are much less likely to ever reach completion, compared to those that start as new students in the fall term.

caption.p: Observed and predicted success rates by program type for 129,143 students in the Connecticut Community College System.
Screen capture of MicroCC setup and simulation run panels gpt analysis of technology versus non-technology majors in Connecticut Community College System 2000-2004 student cohorts.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: MicroCC was designed to explore how microsimulation could improve knowledge and prediction of student success in community colleges, but it can be applied to other college contexts as decision and planning aids for administrators, institutional research directors, evaluators, and other researchers. This microsimulation analysis uncovered that enrollment decisions have huge effects on student success. These student decisions sometimes explain demographic differences. Adding additional variables (e.g., job history, financial aid, and mentoring) as factors in the models would make the methodology even more powerful. The most important policy implication of this analysis is that community colleges may be neglecting to advise students on the importance of enrolling full time and to remain enrolled until their course of study is completed. Further work with MicroCC could extend this potential insight to a broader range of colleges and many more factors in student progress.

sec.title: Statistical Models
sec.p: Note that tables A1 to A3 consist of MicroCC input parameters (logistic coefficients) and tables A4 to A8 are the starting population counts broken down by several variables. Some logistic coefficients are marked with asterisks.

sec.title: MicroCC and Model Download and User Guide
sec.p: The presented model can be downloaded at this location:
Running the model requires the installation of “Modgen prerequisites” from Statistics Canada. This software can be freely downloaded at:

Like all Modgen applications, MicroCC has an attractive visual user interface which allows easy scenario creation and management and access to all model output tables (see Step 1 below). The help system includes a documentation of Modgen as well as a detailed technical documentation of the MicroCC application. The following gives a brief overview of the basic steps required for a model run:

list-item.p: Step 2: Before changing parameters, it is advised to save the scenario under a new name
Step 3: All parameter tables can be accessed easily by selecting a table in the navigation window on the left side of the application.

Step 4: Scenario settings can be set and changed in Scenario/Settings. The most important scenario parameter is the population size; a typical run is 1 million cases. If output is to be produced for smaller population groups, for example a single cohort of a single program, the scenario size can be increased for increased precision.
Step 5: Scenario/run starts the simulation. Simulating 1 million cases typically takes around 30 seconds.

Step 6: Simulation results are presented in a set of tables which can be accessed like parameter tables. Right clicking a table opens a context menu allowing to set for example decimal places, or to display coefficients of variation for each table value.

fn.p: The authors declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

Anderson, Subcontract Director.
